newsitem.title: USA: FDA deputy to lead agency temporarily after Kessler.
newsitem.headline: FDA deputy to lead agency temporarily after Kessler.

text.p: A senior Food and Drug Administration official, Dr. Michael Friedman, will temporarily lead the agency while the search continues for a permanent head, the departing commissioner Dr. David Kessler announced Thursday.

Kessler, who told associates he plans to leave by late February, announced the transitional arrangement in a memo to FDA staff that was later released to reporters. Friedman was described as the "lead deputy commissioner."
"He will perform the duties of commissioner when I depart," Kessler said. "Mike is well prepared to manage the wide range of issues the FDA faces every day."
Friedman was currently the deputy commissioner for operations and had much day-to-day responsibility for FDA management.
Secretary of Health and Human Services Donna Shalala was searching for a permanent replacement for Kessler.
A medical doctor with both managerial and scientific background, Friedman has often been cited as a leading inside candidate.

But many Washington observers expect Shalala to go outside the agency to find a candidate who has not been embroiled by the controversies over teen smoking and drug approval procedures during Kessler's tenure.
